author: By Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay
title: U.S. Adds ‘Kamikaze Drones’ as More Weapons Flow to Ukraine
description: NATO allies are focused on providing Kyiv with high-tech defensive weapons that are easy to use and move.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration will provide Ukraine with additional high-tech defensive weapons that are easily portable and require little training to use against Russian tanks, armored vehicles and aircraft, according to U.S. and European officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic’s recommendations this week include a pirate comedy, a Jane Austen drama and an Australian newsroom show set in 1986.
content: ‘Our Flag Means Death’When to watch: Now, on HBO Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
title: Riding High in the Polls, an Aloof Macron Steps Into the Election Fray
description: The Ukraine war has given the French leader a strong edge and few reasons to engage with his political opponents. He held a news conference to quell criticism that he is avoiding debate.
content: PARIS — Speaking to a country still reeling from a pandemic and made anxious by war in Europe, President Emmanuel Macron of France made his case for a second term on Thursday by portraying himself as best equipped to protect the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Koch Industries will continue to operate its factories in Russia.
description: Koch employs about 600 people in Russia through a unit that makes up a small part of its overall business.
content: Koch Industries, the industrial conglomerate run by the billionaire Charles Koch, has said it will continue to operate factories in Russia as other companies pull out after Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Selena’s Family Announces New Album, 27 Years After Her Death
description: A record featuring the singer’s digitally altered voice is expected to be released by next month, her father said.
content: Nearly three decades after the singer Selena was killed, a new album featuring recordings by the Grammy Award-winning Tejano music star is expected to be released, her family has announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Furman
title: Woody De Othello’s Extraordinary Monuments to the Mundane
description: Ahead of his inclusion in this year’s Whitney Biennial, the emerging sculptor reflects on the spiritual power of domestic spaces.
content: “Home holds a lot of psychic energy,” says the artist Woody De Othello, who’s not referring to the shelter-in-place orders of recent history or to his apartment in Oakland, Calif., but to the concept itself. Domestic scenes recur in much of his work: In brightly colored bronze and ceramic sculptures, he reimagines ordinary household objects — a remote control, faucets — as bulbous, biomorphic forms, some with eyes and ears. As if the result of a solo game of exquisite corpse, these composite creatures are oddly proportioned and at turns alluring and unsettling. Thus, Othello highlights the thrum of spirituality he finds in everyday environments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Patricia Willens, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Four Paths Forward in Ukraine
description: How might the war in Ukraine unfold in the coming weeks or, potentially, months?
content: It has been three weeks since the war in Ukraine began. The fighting grinds on and there is no clear end in sight. But what are the potential paths forward in the coming days and weeks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Laber-Warren
title: The 9-to-5 Schedule Should Be the Next Pillar of Work to Fall
description: The pandemic changed where many of us work. It should also change when we work.
content: Thirty percent of workers around the world surveyed last year said they would consider seeking a new job if their current employer required them to return to the office full time. Millennials are especially resistant. In response to the Covid pandemic, PepsiCo, Meta and General Motors, among others, have incorporated remote work into their corporate cultures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: The Avant-Garde Filmmaker Who Tried to Tell the Truth
description: An innovative retrospective of work by Jonas Mekas reveals the fundamental honesty of his “diary” films.
content: A Lithuanian refugee who landed in New York City in 1949 at the age of 27, Jonas Mekas became a founder of Film Forum, Film Culture magazine and Anthology Film Archives. He was the first full-time critic at The Village Voice, writing about film, and a widely published poet. But he also made scores of collagelike “diary” films that documented his busy, art-filled life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Drought in U.S. Is Expected to Persist, and Spread, Through the Spring
description: Winter precipitation amounts were not enough to significantly improve conditions in much of the country, government scientists said.
content: Drought conditions are likely to continue across more than half of the continental United States through at least June, straining water supplies and increasing the risk of wildfires, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: bona fide
description: This term has appeared in 69 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The term bona fide has appeared in 69 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 1 in “Behind Neil Young vs. Spotify, a Fraught Relationship With Musicians” by Ben Sisario:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Canada eases its Covid rules for fully vaccinated travelers from abroad.
description: Proof of a recent negative test result will no longer be required, though some travelers may still be chosen at random to be tested on arrival.
content: Canada’s coronavirus travel restrictions will be scaled back for fully vaccinated travelers, the government said on Thursday, following a decline in reported coronavirus infections and the country’s success in achieving a high vaccination rate in its population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Republicans Once Silent on Russia Ratchet Up Attacks on Biden
description: Even as they praise the bipartisan congressional response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Republicans are increasingly eager to blame President Biden for the devastation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate Republican news conference on Wednesday was proceeding with the usual partisan criticism of President Biden and exhortations for him to do more — much more — to bolster Ukraine’s defense when the microphone went to Senator Ted Cruz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: With Its Future Uncertain, the Humana Festival Will Not Return in 2022
description: The showcase of work by contemporary American playwrights will not take place this year, either in person or online — and after that, it’s up in the air.
content: Opportunities for emerging playwrights to break into the industry are few — and now there’s one less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Wooley
title: Museum Ships and Submarines Offer History Afloat
description: According to the National Park Service, some 120 vessels in the United States are designated as national historic landmarks.
content: While the discovery of the Endurance — Ernest Shackleton’s ship that sank in an ill-fated Antarctic expedition in 1915 — made international headlines last week, the wreck is expected to remain at the bottom of the Weddell Sea, far from any interested members of the general public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Do I Really Need to Tip for Drip Coffee?
description: A reader is turned off by a local shop’s new gratuity-seeking efforts.
content: I managed to get past my annoyance at the tip jar that appeared one day on the counter of my local coffee shop. (Tipping for what? Pouring coffee? Handing me a muffin?) But apparently that wasn’t enough. Now the proprietors have added a “tip screen” to the credit card payment process, reminding me to pay their workers for them in case I missed the tip jar on the counter. I am sick of being asked for handouts for people who are simply doing their jobs. No one has ever tipped me in my modestly paying job as a teacher. I would really like to say something to the owner of the shop. May I?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Cheaper by the Dozen’ Review: Keep the Family Close
description: Gabrielle Union and Zach Braff manage a very busy household in the latest adaptation of the popular novel.
content: “Cheaper by the Dozen,” the 1948 novel by the siblings Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr. and Ernestine Gilbreth Carey, based on their experiences growing up in a household of 12 children, has been adapted for the screen multiple times now, with an increasing lack of fidelity. The latest take, directed by Gail Lerner with a screenplay by Jenifer Rice-Genzuk Henry and the “black-ish” creator Kenya Barris, bears virtually no resemblance to the source material: Instead of a husband-and-wife duo of industrial engineers living in New Jersey with a dozen biological children, this “Cheaper” tells the story of the Bakers, Paul (Zach Braff) and Zoe (Gabrielle Union), who own a popular Los Angeles diner and share a home with their adopted son, a teenage nephew, two sets of twins and a slew of kids from previous marriages. The only thing the movie has in common with the book is that it’s about a big family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: N.L.R.B. sues Amazon over labor practices at a Staten Island facility.
description: The labor agency wants a federal judge to order changes there in the case of a fired worker before a union election starts next week.
content: The National Labor Relations Board sued Amazon in federal court on Thursday, asking a judge to force the company to swiftly rectify what it called “flagrant unfair labor practices” before workers at one of its Staten Island warehouses begin voting in a union election next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. Will Punish China if It Gives Military Aid to Russia, Blinken Says
description: President Biden plans to talk on Friday with Xi Jinping, who has a close partnership with Vladimir V. Putin and supports him in the Ukraine war.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Thursday that the United States would punish China if President Xi Jinping chose to give military aid to Russia for the war in Ukraine, where Russian forces have killed thousands of civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Four Financial Tips for Buying a Second Home
description: Second homes are becoming more expensive, and house hunters should examine interest rates, upfront fees, maintenance charges and taxes when calculating the cost.
content: Demand for second homes has ramped up in the last couple of years as affluent Americans fled dense cities for more elbow room and a better view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Torch’ Review: The Blues Legend Buddy Guy Sows His Legacy
description: A new documentary by Jim Farrell focuses on the musician’s sense of mission.
content: This documentary centered on the blues musician Buddy Guy is a very good rather than a great movie. But any opportunity to spend almost two hours in the company of Buddy Guy is an opportunity not to be missed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Ahed’s Knee’ Review: A Filmmaker’s Agony in the Desert
description: Nadav Lapid’s new film, about a brooding director much like himself, is a howl of rage at the state of Israeli society.
content: “Ahed’s Knee” is the Israeli director Nadav Lapid’s fourth feature film. The first three — “Policeman” (2014), “The Kindergarten Teacher” (2015) and “Synonyms” (2019) — are in their different ways works of social criticism. They take aim at what Lapid sees as modern Israel’s political, moral and spiritual shortcomings, focusing on characters whose personal agonies mirror the national crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: A ‘Lost City’ Group Chat With Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum and Daniel Radcliffe
description: Their movie comedy will be under close scrutiny at the box office. But they aren’t fazed and have lots to say about that Brad Pitt cameo, “Magic Mike” and “Harry Potter.”
content: They play potential lovers in “The Lost City,” but in real life, Sandra Bullock and Channing Tatum share a very different kind of bond: They’re play-date parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Following the Beat of the Court
description: The Supreme Court reporter Adam Liptak on his path to The Times, how he approaches covering the court and his daily routine.
content: Adam Liptak, who covers the United States Supreme Court for The Times, has had an unconventional journey to his current job — but it’s that same journey that suits him so well for the role. He started at the newspaper in 1984 as what was then called a copy boy, an entry-level position that involved fetching coffee and distributing paper copies of wire-service stories to editors around the newsroom. After about a year, he went to Yale Law School, and in 1992 he returned to work in The Times’s corporate legal department. A decade later, he joined the newsroom as the national legal reporter and then moved to the Supreme Court beat in 2008. Here he talks about his career path, what he misses about practicing law — very little — and how he approaches the court’s docket each term. This interview has been edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘The Medium’ Is Less a Message and More a Museum Piece
description: This early 1990s play, based on the life of Marshall McLuhan, is being revived by the company that created it.
content: “You can’t go home again.”

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
description: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.
content: Ukraine’s government is “openly neo-Nazi” and “pro-Nazi,” controlled by “little Nazis,” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says.

title: See ‘Spot’ Save: Robot Dogs Join the New York Fire Department
description: Plans to use two new robot dogs only in precarious search and rescue missions may help avoid the controversy that met the Police Department’s robots last year.
content: Inside a dimly lit tunnel along a stretch of simulated subway track, one of the New York Fire Department’s new dogs showed off a few of its tricks. Lie down. Roll over. Stay.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Bus Shooting in Florida Leaves 2 Dead and 2 Injured
description: The bus driver was hailed for driving swiftly to Police Headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, at one point veering into oncoming lanes. A suspect surrendered after the bus came to a stop.
content: A gunman fatally shot two people and wounded two others aboard a public bus in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Thursday afternoon near the city’s Police Headquarters, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Grace Ashford and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Push for More Restrictive Bail Law Gains a Key Ally: Gov. Hochul
description: Ms. Hochul wants to expand the list of crimes eligible for bail in New York, and give judges the power to consider the danger a defendant poses in setting bail for certain crimes.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul, responding to a number of high-profile crimes that have rattled New Yorkers and to a sharp rise in gun violence during the pandemic, is privately pushing state lawmakers to change the state’s contentious bail law, according to an internal memo obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Raised by Wolves’ Is TV’s Wildest Hallucination
description: This strange but transfixing HBO Max sci-fi series takes an act of faith to enjoy.
content: If you have not yet seen “Raised by Wolves,” you will probably not understand it when you first start watching. Don’t worry; that’s why I wrote you this article. But you will not understand “Raised by Wolves” after you read this article either. You will not understand it by the end of the first season, nor the second, which ends Thursday on HBO Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Ham
title: Australia’s Clever Birds Did Not Consent to This Science Experiment
description: The magpies showed their smarts by helping one another remove tracking harnesses that scientists carefully placed on them.
content: The Australian magpie is one of the cleverest birds on earth. It has a beautiful song of extraordinary complexity. It can recognize and remember up to 30 different human faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Former Louisville Officer Who Fired Pepper Balls Is Indicted
description: The act preceded a volley in which a popular barbecue chef, David McAtee, was fatally shot by a National Guard member.
content: A federal grand jury on Wednesday indicted a former police officer in Louisville, Ky., on a charge that she used unreasonable force in firing pepper balls at a person to try to enforce a curfew during protests against police violence in 2020 — an act that led to the fatal shooting of a popular barbecue chef by a Kentucky National Guard member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Why Arnold Schwarzenegger taped an impassioned video to Russia, telling Putin: ‘Stop this war.’
description: The movie star and former governor of California addressed Russians and Russian soldiers, saying, “ “your lives, your limbs, your futures are being sacrificed for a senseless war.”
content: In an emotional video posted across social media on Thursday, Arnold Schwarzenegger debunked Russian disinformation about the war on Ukraine and told President Vladimir V. Putin: “You started this war. You are leading this war. You can stop this war.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Confessions of a Wedding Hater
description: I found it so easy to judge other people’s ceremonies. Then, along came Thomas.
content: If you’re reading this, and I attended your wedding, I’d like to apologize for my behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Honduras Judge Approves Extradition of Ex-President to U.S.
description: Former President Juan Orlando Hernández is facing drug-trafficking and weapons charges
content: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Former President Juan Orlando Hernández should be extradited to the United States to face drug-trafficking and weapons charges, a Honduran judge ruled on Wednesday.

title: What Is Our Moral Obligation in Ukraine?
description: The U.S. should supply aid to Ukraine. But we must be more consistent in determining who deserves humanitarian intervention.
content: In 1994, I was a young journalist in the information graphics department at The Detroit News, just two years out of college.

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Outfit’ Review: The Violent Measure of a Man
description: In this gangster exercise set in 1956 Chicago, Mark Rylance plays a tailor who has very large scissors and some sharp moves.
content: The gangsters in “The Outfit” have plenty of tough moves, but none of these guys hold the screen like Mark Rylance when he just stands or stares — or sews. His character, Leonard, is a bespoke tailor who once worked on Savile Row and now practices his trade in an unassuming shop in Chicago. There, he snips and stitches with a bowed head and delicate, precisely articulated movements that express the beauty and grace of Rylance’s art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: One Pizza at a Time, He Defined the New York Slice
description: Domenico DeMarco, who founded Di Fara Pizza in 1965, has died. He was a link between the cooking of Southern Italy and the city’s corner-slice culture.
content: I first saw Domenico DeMarco in action more than 20 years ago, although if you ever saw him at work you know that there was hardly any action to see unless you watched him very closely.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Some of the Tech Magic Is Gone
description: The bubble hasn’t exactly burst, but we’re no longer seeing a fantastical belief in the power of technology.
content: At this point in 2021, technology was eating the world and stock markets.

title: Working Remotely, Some Transgender People Saw an Opportunity to Change
description: After transitioning in private, they are preparing to return to the workplace at a time when gender identity itself is a politically divisive issue.
content: For years, Deke Wilson, 41, was ambivalent about undergoing a medical transition to male. He felt it was critical for his happiness, but there were plenty of reasons to put it off: the expense, the difficult recovery, the potential medical complications.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Friday Briefing: The Destruction of Ukraine
description: Plus South Korea’s new approach to the virus and Cambodia’s crackdown on opposition leaders.
content: In Ukraine, workers struggled to rescue survivors from a theater in Mariupol that had been sheltering up to 1,000 civilians, including children, and was largely destroyed in an attack. It was unclear how many people survived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Sharon Otterman
title: What New York Got Wrong About the Pandemic, and What It Got Right
description: The city was slow to react, and the vaccine rollout was flawed. Poor neighborhoods still need help. But shutdowns and mandates saved lives.
content: Just over two years ago, a middle-aged lawyer arrived at a Westchester County hospital, struggling to breathe. What ailed him remained a mystery for days until, on March 2, he tested positive for the new coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: The Art of Making Thai Noodles, Far From Thailand
description: Cooks in the nation’s diaspora offer wisdom on making pad Thai and other classics at home. First tip: Sometimes taste is more important than tradition.
content: In Thailand, pad Thai, pad see ew and pad kee mao are just three of countless popular noodle dishes. But at Thai restaurants elsewhere, they are canon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Jane by Charlotte’ Review: A Mother-Daughter Duet
description: Charlotte Gainsbourg makes her directorial debut with an elusive portrait of her mother, the French-English star Jane Birkin, at age 74.
content: “Jane by Charlotte,” the directorial debut of the actress and singer Charlotte Gainsbourg (“Antichrist”), is a meandering and elusive documentary portrait of Gainsbourg’s mother, Jane Birkin. An “It” girl of the 1960s and ’70s, Birkin is known for starring in risqué art-house films (like “Blow-Up”), and for her romance with Serge Gainsbourg, with whom she collaborated on a hit album before starting her solo singing career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Why Stacey Abrams Isn’t Embracing Her Democratic Stardom (So Far)
description: On the campaign trail for Georgia governor, she is talking more about Medicaid expansion than voting rights, betting that a hyperlocal strategy and the state’s leftward tilt can lift her to victory.
content: CUTHBERT, Ga. — As Stacey Abrams began her second campaign for Georgia governor with a speech this week about Medicaid expansion in front of a shuttered rural hospital, the crowd of about 50 peppered her with questions on issues like paving new roads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: L.G.B.T.Q. activists in Ukraine share the fight against Russia’s invasion.
description: A pro-Russian puppet government would be less supportive of gay rights, the activists say, and incidents of discrimination would be likely to rise, as they have in Russian-backed separatist regions.
content: To look at videos from last year’s Pride Parade in Kyiv is to peer at a joyous moment of solidarity in the quest for gay rights in Ukraine. A video on YouTube shows a cheerful crowd of thousands. Some wave flags. Some carry banners. Drag queens dance on a float.

title: What Has Been Lost in Kharkiv
description: Russian forces are destroying Ukraine’s second-largest city.

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Mortgage rates hit 4 percent for the first time in 3 years.
description: The average rate on 30-year fixed mortgages dropped as low as 2.65 percent in January 2021.
content: Mortgage rates topped 4 percent this week for the first time in nearly three years — and are expected to keep climbing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Love After Love’ Review: Elegance Without a Center
description: Ann Hui’s World War II-era film is lovely to look at but lacks emotional depth and resonance.
content: Early on in “Love After Love,” the director Ann Hui introduces the viewer to an astonishing shade of green, an emerald lushness that radiates from the foliage surrounding a Hong Kong mansion on the eve of World War II. If only the rest of the overlong feature were so memorable.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Life’ Review: Turning More Than a Few New Tricks
description: Billy Porter brings a heavy-handed touch as the director and adapter of this 1997 musical about prostitutes and pimps in Manhattan’s bad old days.
content: In case you have forgotten the premise behind Reaganomics, the musical “The Life” offers a primer right before a big number at the top of Act 2: It was based on “the proposition that taxes on businesses should be reduced as a means to stimulate business investment in the short term and benefit society at large in the long term.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: In Ohio, a Standoff Over Political Maps Threatens the Next Elections
description: Years ago, voters created a commission to make political maps fairer. Now the State Supreme Court is blocking maps drawn by the Republican-led commission, saying nothing has changed.
content: A bipartisan majority of Ohio Supreme Court justices has ratcheted up an extraordinary legal standoff over the state’s political boundaries, rejecting — for the third time in barely two months — new maps of state legislative districts that heavily favor the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: For Car Designers, E.V.s Offer a Blank Canvas
description: Frunks are just the start — think Cybertruck, not Focus.
content: The internal combustion engine is exiting stage left. While it provided great transportation and performance thrills for many years, it will no longer play a leading role. In its place under the hood will be, well, very little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: Will Inflation Fix Itself?
description: That appears to be what the Federal Reserve is counting on.
content: The Fed, as expected, raised interest rates yesterday, by a quarter of a point. It is the start of what will most likely be a monthslong, if not yearslong, campaign to tame the worst bout of inflation in decades without damaging the economic recovery that the central bank’s efforts during the pandemic helped foment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | March 23, 2022
description: Since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, 2022, almost three million of the country’s 44 million residents have left the country. How big is this crisis?
content: Special Announcement for March: The American Statistical Association is now running its annual This is Statistics Spring Contest. author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: A ‘Punk Ballerina’ Turns to Film and Fashion
description: In “A Pandemic Notebook,” the choreographer Karole Armitage presents her final program of new works. And, with Jock Soto, she returns to the stage.
content: What does it mean when a prolific choreographer declares that she will stop presenting new works? That’s what the choreographer Karole Armitage, who came of age during the 1980s, has done. But dance is hard. Maybe she is done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: With a Fourth World Cup Overall Title, Mikaela Shiffrin Is Back on Top
description: The skier said she was “embarrassed” by failing to win a medal in any of her five Beijing Olympic events. Turns out she was in it for the yearlong haul.
content: Mikaela Shiffrin had just finished eating lunch on Thursday in the picturesque French Alps village of Courchevel. An hour earlier, with a second-place finish in a super-G race — one day after a victory in a downhill race — Shiffrin clinched the World Cup’s season-long overall title, ski racing’s biggest prize, representing the highest achiever in a globe-trotting, six-month, 37-race marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Michelle Goldberg, Bret Stephens and David Brooks
title: Opinion Round Table: ‘A Weak Putin Could Turn Into a Nuclear-Deploying Putin’
description: Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Michelle Goldberg, Bret Stephens and David Brooks discuss the latest developments in Russia’s Ukraine war.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the refugee crisis in Eastern Europe are intensifying as the war enters its fourth week. On Wednesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine appealed to Congress to do more, pleading for a no-fly zone, more weapons and more sanctions on Russia. President Biden is set to meet with NATO allies and E.U. leaders next week, while the West navigates the reality of war at its doorstep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 13-Year-Old Boy Drove Truck That Hit Van in Texas, Killing 9, Officials Say
description: The fiery crash killed a golf coach and six of his players, along with the boy and a man who was traveling with him.
content: A 13-year-old boy was behind the wheel of a pickup truck that struck a van in Texas on Tuesday night in a collision that killed nine people, including a college golf coach and six of his players, along with the boy and a man traveling with him, officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Largest Federal Utility Chooses Gas, Undermining Biden’s Climate Goals
description: President Biden wants electricity generated from wind, solar and other clean sources. The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to invest in fossil fuels instead.
content: WASHINGTON — The nation’s largest federally owned utility plans to invest more than $3.5 billion in new gas-burning electric plants, despite President Biden’s commitment to swiftly move away from fossil fuels and eliminate greenhouse gases from the power sector in a little more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: While Scrolling Through Netflix
description: Daniel Bodily makes his New York Times Crossword debut, ably abetted by Jeff Chen.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When my children were younger, my way of communicating to them that they had pushed past my limit and needed to tidy their living areas evolved, over time, into a game. Games are fun, and they aid children in learning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: How to Press Tofu
description: Get more crisp and crunch from your firm tofu — no special equipment required!
content: If you cook firm tofu a lot, maybe you already know this: Pressing the tofu compresses it and squeezes out extra moisture, making it firmer and drier, which means you can get a more densely closegrained interior and wonderfully crisp exterior when you cook it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Walking a Tightrope, Atlanta Says Goodbye to a Star
description: Freddie Freeman led Atlanta to a World Series title, but a general manager known to “regroup and fortify” made a difficult and pragmatic decision to make a change.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Dansby Swanson gathered the final ground ball of the World Series last November, then peeked to second base for an easy force that would have clinched the title for the Atlanta Braves. When his double play partner, Ozzie Albies, was slow to break for the bag, Swanson changed direction and threw to first instead. Freddie Freeman, ever dependable, was sure to be there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Ed O'Loughlin, Alyssa Lukpat, Emily Cochrane, Adeel Hassan and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Biden cancels in-person meetings with the Irish prime minister, who tested positive for the coronavirus.
description: The prime minister’s test result came amid a burst of infections among public officials in Washington in recent days.
content: President Biden canceled his face-to-face meetings with Prime Minister Micheal Martin of Ireland on Thursday after the prime minister received a positive result on a coronavirus test during a gala event in Washington on Wednesday night that both men attended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Deep Water’ Review: Love and Loathing in New Orleans
description: An unhappy husband raises suspicions when his wife’s lovers begin to disappear.
content: Two decades have passed since Adrian Lyne made “Unfaithful,” maybe his best film, though not his best known. (That would be his 1987 sizzler, “Fatal Attraction.”) A slickly accomplished purveyor of the erotic thriller, Lyne doesn’t make love stories so much as lust stories — specifically, the way an incorrigible sexual appetite can rip a life apart.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why a ‘Peanuts’ Collection Has Stuck With Jeremy Denk, Concert Pianist
description: “‘Peanuts Vol. 3’ (I think) ... made it cool to be excited about Beethoven’s birthday.”
content: “‘Peanuts Vol. 3’ (I think) … made it cool to be excited about Beethoven’s birthday,” says the musician Jeremy Denk, whose new memoir is “Every Good Boy Does Fine.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Disruption! Chaos! Pandemonium! It’s not much fun to live through, but in hindsight it can make for pretty good copy — so it’s not surprising to find, at the center of this week’s recommended titles, that the center doesn’t hold. NoViolet Bulawayo’s new novel, “Glory,” is all about political turmoil. Yoko Tawada’s latest, “Scattered All Over the Earth,” is about climate apocalypse. Two new biographies of Buster Keaton make the case that he was not only a comic genius but also a technological disrupter, madly innovating new directions for the film industry in its early days. And in “Origin,” Jennifer Raff sets out to overturn some long-held theories about the first humans to populate the Americas. Things fall apart. That’s the message of “The Quiet Before,” by Gal Beckerman (until recently my colleague at the Book Review), about social movements building from the ground up, and it’s the premise (in a very different way) of “The Old Woman With the Knife,” Gu Byeong-mo’s novel about a 65-year-old female assassin in Seoul. Meanwhile, disruption of another sort — aesthetic, existential — is at the core of the Swedish writer Jon Fosse’s seven-novel series “Septology,” about an aging painter arguing with God. Happy reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tali Farhadian Weinstein
title: The Question Juror No. 50 in Ghislaine Maxwell’s Trial Should Never Have Been Asked
description: Juror No. 50 in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial withheld his history of abuse. That doesn’t make him a bad juror.
content: During jury selection for the high-profile sex crimes trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, a confidential questionnaire presented by the court asked potential jurors, “Have you or a friend or a family member ever been the victim of sexual harassment, sexual abuse or sexual assault?” Juror No. 50 checked the box for “no.” After the trial, Juror No. 50 revealed that, during deliberations, he told his fellow jurors that he had been sexually abused as a child and for years had kept this abuse a secret. The court must now decide whether Juror No. 50’s failure to tell the truth requires invalidating Ms. Maxwell’s convictions and granting her a new trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: UNESCO will send body armor to Ukrainian journalists.
description: The U.N. agency said thousands of Ukrainian journalists with no protective equipment or training were now covering the war. At least four journalists have been killed.
content: YEREVAN, Armenia — The United Nations’ cultural agency said on Thursday that it was sending body armor and helmets to Ukraine to help protect Ukrainian journalists, many of whom have gone from covering local news to suddenly becoming war correspondents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: USAA is fined $140 million for bad money laundering controls.
description: Regulators say the bank, which mainly serves U.S. military members, failed to keep track of its customers’ suspicious activities despite repeated warnings that it needed to improve.
content: Federal regulators have fined USAA Federal Savings Bank, a century-old institution that mainly does business with members and veterans of the U.S. military, for failing to follow anti-money laundering laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A City Under Siege
description: We give you a rare dispatch from Mariupol, Ukraine.
content: Mariupol — in southeastern Ukraine, near the Russian border — has been under siege for more than two weeks. It is the city where Russia last week bombed a maternity hospital and yesterday attacked a theater that hundreds of civilians were using as a shelter. It was unclear how many of those sheltering survived, according to a Ukrainian official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Gig Workers Say High Gas Prices May Be a Breaking Point
description: Some drivers say they find it hard to justify spending hours on the road for Uber or Lyft as fuel costs continue to tick upward.
content: When Adam Potash started driving for Lyft six months ago to help make ends meet, he was happy with the pay. The business was far from lucrative, but he was making about $200 a day before paying for costs like gas and car maintenance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: This Is Why Autocracies Fail
description: Over the long term, centralized power is a recipe for stagnation.
content: Joe Biden correctly argues that the struggle between democracy and autocracy is the defining conflict of our time. So which system performs better under stress?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Republicans Push Crackdown on Crime Wave That Doesn’t Exist: Voter Fraud
description: Election fraud is exceedingly rare and often accidental. Still, G.O.P. lawmakers and prosecutors are promoting tough new enforcement efforts.
content: The Florida Legislature last week created a law enforcement agency — informally called the election police — to tackle what Gov. Ron DeSantis and other Republicans have declared an urgent problem: the roughly 0.000677 percent of voters suspected of committing voter fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Two Years of the Pandemic: New York Looks Back
description: It all began in March 2020, when we were flying blind and hoping it would be over quickly.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at two years of the coronavirus pandemic. We’ll also look at a new kind of skating rink that is coming to Rockefeller Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Pinkham
title: ‘They’re Willing to Risk Ruining Their Lives.’ Putin’s War Is Driving Russians Out.
description: Russia is witnessing its greatest mass exodus since the revolution.
content: The eyes of the world are focused on the millions of Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s brutal invasion. But Russians are fleeing their own country too, at a speed most likely not seen since the collapse of the Soviet Union. They are running not from foreign bombs but from their own government. Rumors of impending martial law, closed borders, conscription and punitive military service have fueled panic. Amid state shutdowns of almost all of the last major independent media outlets and the announcement of draconian punishment for any coverage or criticism of Vladimir Putin’s war on Ukraine, tens or even hundreds of thousands of members of Russia’s liberal intelligentsia and political opposition are scrambling to escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The Bank of England raises rates again in a bid to corral inflation.
description: The bank on Thursday lifted its key interest rate to 0.75 percent, the third consecutive increase.
content: The Bank of England raised interest rates to their prepandemic level on Thursday in an effort to combat rapidly accelerating inflation that has been worsened by the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imogen West-Knights
title: A Show About European Identity Opens With a Backdrop of War
description: Jasmina Cibic’s new exhibition explores the theatricality of nation building in Europe. She didn’t expect it to have such immediate contemporary relevance.
content: When the first visitors arrived at Jasmina Cibic’s new show at the Museum der Moderne in Salzburg, Austria, earlier this month, they were met by a pile of rubble. The room was also filled with a scent created from rose varieties named after the founding fathers of a united Europe — figures like Charles de Gaulle, the former president of France, and Robert Schuman, one of the founders of NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Alyssa Lukpat
title: For some transgender people, remote work meant a chance to take the next steps in their transitions.
description: After transitioning in private, some transgender people are preparing to return to the workplace at a time when gender identity itself is a politically divisive issue.
content: After transitioning in private, some transgender people are preparing to return to the workplace at a time when gender identity itself is a politically divisive issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Stars Battle It Out on London Stages
description: In West End productions, Jonathan Bailey and Taron Egerton play a fighting couple, and Kit Harington from “Game of Thrones” plays the warrior king in “Henry V.”
content: LONDON — There’s no nudity in “Cock,” the 2009 Mike Bartlett play that opened Tuesday in a starry revival at the Ambassadors Theater here. But by the time its 105 minutes, no intermission, have come to an end, you’ve seen its characters stripped emotionally bare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Russian Court Extends Brittney Griner’s Detention
description: Griner, one of the world’s best basketball players, was detained on accusations that she had hashish oil in her luggage at an airport outside of Moscow a week before Russia invaded Ukraine.
content: A Russian court has extended the detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner to May 19, the Russian news agency Tass reported on Thursday, adding tension to the most dangerous moment in U.S.-Russia relations since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Eugene N. Parker, 94, Dies; Predicted the Existence of Solar Wind
description: At first, almost no one believed his findings on gigantic eruptions from the sun. Today, a NASA mission to fly through its outer atmosphere is named after him.
content: Eugene N. Parker, the astrophysicist who predicted the existence of the solar wind, a continuous outpouring of charged particles traveling from the sun at a million miles per hour, died on Tuesday at his home in Chicago. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Robert Chiarito
title: The Jussie Smollett Case Is Probably Far From Over, Analysts Say
description: The Illinois appellate court that ordered Mr. Smollett’s release from jail often takes months, even years, to rule on cases, according to experts.
content: After serving six days of a five-month sentence, Jussie Smollett walked out of Cook County Jail on Wednesday night, flanked by supporters who shepherded him into the back seat of an SUV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Penny
title: Campbell Addy Up Close
description: The photographer of the moment on what it takes to be seen.
content: LONDON — On a cold, wet day in South London, Campbell Addy, the Ghanaian-British photographer, filmmaker and artist, opened the door to his studio, grinning. He was wearing denim overalls, an exuberant corduroy baker boy cap from Nicholas Daley, an oversize rust-colored scarf and Doc Martens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Life & Beth’ Review: Further Inside Amy Schumer
description: A Hulu series about a frustrated wine rep re-examining her past has connections to the comedian’s Long Island childhood.
content: Amy Schumer has not been absent from television during the six years since the end of her intermittently brilliant sketch show, “Inside Amy Schumer.” She’s had a couple of Netflix stand-up specials and made a detour into reality TV (“Amy Schumer Learns to Cook,” “Expecting Amy”). Next week she’ll be an Oscars host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Inflation vs. Recession: The Fed Is Walking a Tightrope
description: American consumers already have high inflation. Because of the oil price shock and Russia’s war, the odds of a recession have increased, too.
content: Even before Russia invaded Ukraine, the Federal Reserve was in a tough spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abigail A. Dumes
title: What Long Covid Shows Us About the Limits of Medicine
description: Contested illnesses reveal the limits of conventional medicine.
content: Long Covid symptoms, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, cognitive difficulties, erratic heart rate, headache and dizziness, can be debilitating and wide-ranging. There is uncertainty about what ultimately causes long Covid and how to adequately respond to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Wong and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Lessons on Lessening
description: Jane Wong’s poem grapples with the making of a self that’s dependent on childhood, history, comparison and societal expectations.
content: Jane Wong’s poem grapples with the making of a self that’s dependent on childhood, history, comparison and societal expectations. Growing up can be overwhelming as we figure out where we came from, who we are and where we are going (all at once!). Wong writes, “I was taught that everything and everyone is self-made,” but the speaker is realizing that life will come with its own surprises, regardless of our intent, or anyone else’s. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amid Invasion of Ukraine, I.R.S. Aims to Police Oligarch Sanctions
description: It wants to add agents to a 3,000-person investigations unit to help crack down on attempts by Russian oligarchs to evade sanctions.
content: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service is pressing Congress to devote more resources to the agency as it takes an increasingly central role in the Biden administration’s efforts to prevent Russia and its oligarchs from evading the punishing sanctions that the United States has imposed.

title: My Bracket Has a Final Score Tiebreaker. What Should I Write In?
description: Here’s a look at the average scores and average combined scores of recent college basketball national championship games.
content: You’ve methodically filled out your N.C.A.A. basketball tournament bracket, choosing winners of 63 games using extensive research, surefire strategy and deep knowledge of the field. Now, there’s just one remaining field: a tiebreaker question asking for a prediction for the final score of the championship game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Kathy Griffin Wants the World to Stop Thinking She Did Something Wrong
description: The comedian explains why she “takes umbrage” with the term “cancellation,” and how her career still hasn’t fully recovered.
content: Whether it’s Andrew Cuomo or Dave Chappelle, everyone these days, it seems, is blaming “cancel culture” for career problems. But five years ago, Kathy Griffin was a canary in the coal mine, being canceled for reasons she says were overblown. In 2017, a photo in which she posed with a mask styled to look like Donald Trump’s severed head went viral. She says it was clearly comedy, yet she faced a Secret Service investigation as well as death threats from Trump supporters. She was also virtually blacklisted from her industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and John Yoon
title: In South Korea, a Spike in Covid Cases Meets a Collective Shrug
description: A country that once had one of the world’s most aggressive coronavirus policies is opting to learn to live with the virus, even in the face of a soaring infection rate.
content: SEOUL — South Korea reported its peak daily coronavirus infection number of the entire pandemic on Thursday, recording 621,328 cases in a country of 50 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks and Declan Walsh
title: ‘Finish Them Off’: Aid Workers, Found on Battlefield, Executed by Soldiers
description: Three employees of Doctors Without Borders set out to rescue the wounded in a war zone in northern Ethiopia. Their fate shows the treacherous path for many aid workers in conflict zones.
content: This story was supported by the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Votes to Suspend Normal Trade Relations With Russia
description: The bill, which still needs Senate approval, is the latest in a series of measures that lawmakers have passed to support Ukraine and punish Russia for its invasion.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to strip Russia of its preferential trade status with the United States, moving to further penalize the country’s economy in response to the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Video Appears to Show Death of California Man Held Down by Police
description: “I can’t breathe,” Edward Bronstein yelled as highway patrol officers pinned him down after a traffic stop in Burbank in March 2020, a video released this week shows.
content: Two years ago, Edward Bronstein was pulled over in Burbank, Calif., by California Highway Patrol officers who believed he was driving under the influence of a narcotic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: By Labeling Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Biden Personalizes the Conflict
description: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden declared to reporters on Wednesday, almost off the cuff, that President Vladimir V. Putin was a “war criminal,” he was speaking from the heart, his aides said, reacting to the wrenching images of civilians — including children — being dragged, dead or disfigured, from ruins of buildings shelled by Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Confetti
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beandrea July
title: ‘Alice’ Review: American Slavery and Black Power Collide
description: This time-bending thriller about a woman who escapes from slavery in 1973, starring Keke Palmer and Common, is a vapid historical romp.
content: In “Alice,” a coming-of-age revenge thriller from the writer-director Krystin Ver Linden, the eponymous main character (Keke Palmer, “Akeelah and the Bee,” “Hustlers”) successfully flees an abusive enslaver (Jonny Lee Miller) only to discover the year is actually 1973. Yes, 1973, and she and her fellow “domestics” have been trapped in a century-old bubble on a Georgia plantation, where not much has changed since Emancipation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Cauliflower Shawarma Reaches for Spring
description: A vegetarian take on the Middle Eastern dish, this recipe straddles the seasons.
content: These earliest days of spring are always the most frustrating, at least when it comes to dinner. Although the weather is getting milder and there’s that distinct earthy-sharp scent wafting through my Brooklyn farmers’ market, the stalls remain largely a barren field of potato-beige and onion skin-brown, with any leafy green bounty still many weeks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Camille Norment Explores New Sonic Terrains at Dia Chelsea
description: The composer and sculptor, born in America and based in Norway, presents two installations on the border of art and music.
content: In the late 1960s and 1970s, the best place to hear new music was often not a concert hall, but an art gallery. Back then, while Carnegie Hall and the still-new Lincoln Center played it safe uptown, the minimalist composer Steve Reich was presenting his rhythmic, exacting compositions down at the Park Place Gallery, led by Paula Cooper. You could hear Philip Glass’s “Music in 12 Parts” at Leo Castelli Gallery, or Meredith Monk’s a cappella ululations at the Walker Art Center. Composers and artists collaborated with ease — La Monte Young wrote compositions for the sculptor Robert Morris; Glass assisted Richard Serra in the creation of his early splashes of lead — and the very distinction between new art and new music could be hazy: the Fluxus artists Nam June Paik, George Maciunas, Allan Kaprow and Yoko Ono were all trained in music composition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Panama’ Review: Welcome to the Jungle, We Lack Fun and Games
description: Mel Gibson drops in from time to time in this predictable throwback thriller from Mark Neveldine.
content: There is absolutely no need to brush up on geopolitics for Mark Neveldine’s macho thriller “Panama,” which might be a blessing: This over-plotted yet utterly predictable throwback is set in the waning days of Manuel Noriega’s presidency, when sorting out the C.I.A.’s allegiances in Central America was trickier than playing three-card monte. The movie is more interested in resurrecting the spirit of action flicks from the late 1980s, a time when men were brutes, women were pawns or eye candy, and declarative assertions passed for dialogue. “Nothing more rock ‘n’ roll,” Mel Gibson’s Stark whoops here, “than taking out the bad guys for the red, white and blue!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Orr
title: In Defense of Poetry
description: In “Rhyme’s Rooms,” the veteran poet and avowed traditionalist Brad Leithauser explains how verse works, and why we should care.
content: RHYME’S ROOMSThe Architecture of PoetryBy Brad Leihauser
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: The End of the Endless Final Set: Grand Slams Adopt Same Tiebreaker
description: The French Open was the last major tennis tournament that allowed an “advantage final set” without a tiebreaker. Once the maker of many classic, marathon matches, the system is no more.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Tennis is entering a new era: one in which the marathon final sets that have concluded some of its greatest and longest matches are no longer an option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: U.S. News Ranked Columbia No. 2, but a Math Professor Has His Doubts
description: A professor identified several data discrepancies that Columbia University provided to U.S. News & World Report, renewing the debate over the value and accuracy of college rankings.
content: Everyone knows that students buff their résumés when applying to college. But a math professor is accusing Columbia University of buffing its own résumé — or worse — to climb the all-important U.S. News & World Report rankings of best universities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Yuri Milner’s Russian Clapback
description: A Russian-born tech titan takes a bold stance against his birth country’s pummeling of Ukraine.
content: As the war in Ukraine continues, the widening, noisy and at times confusing battle between Facebook’s parent, Meta, and Vladimir Putin’s government has generated its fair share of headlines. So a critique from one of Facebook’s earliest — and perhaps most important — investors may have slipped your notice. But it is a critical development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello and Sinna Nasseri
title: Where Jazz Lives Now
description: The jazz club, with its dim lighting and closely packed tables, looms large in our collective imagination. But today, the music is thriving in a host of different spaces.
content: A disco ball threw beads of light across a crowded dance floor on a recent Monday night in Lower Manhattan while old film footage rolled across a wall by the stage. A half-dozen musicians were up there, churning waves of rhythm that reshaped over time: A transition might start with a double-tap of chords, reggae-style, from the keyboardist Ray Angry, or with a new vocal line, improvised and looped by the singer Kamilah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: In a First, a Cardinal Testifies in a Vatican Criminal Trial
description: Accused of embezzlement and abuse of office, Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu told the court that he was sure the truth would clear his name.
content: VATICAN CITY — The first cardinal to face a criminal trial in a Vatican courtroom, once one of the Roman Catholic Church’s most powerful officials, told the court in the papal city-state on Thursday that he was ready to clear his name against charges of embezzlement and abuse of office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: More U.S. military aid for Ukraine.
content: Russian forces destroyed a theater in the coastal Ukrainian city of Mariupol where about 1,000 people had been sheltering yesterday, in a day of intensifying brutality. At least 10 people were killed by shelling in Chernihiv, north of Kyiv, as they waited in line for bread. Russia’s Defense Ministry denied carrying out the attack on Mariupol. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: Back to the Past
description: “Star Trek” has historically been at its best when dabbling in time travel, and this week’s episode found it doing so again.
content: “Star Trek” has historically been at its best when dabbling in time travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Intregalde’ Review: Oh, Be Good!
description: A Romanian satire charts what happens when some humanitarian aid workers set out to save others (and need to be saved themselves).
content: Beware of laughing when watching “Intregalde” because your laughs will have a way of catching — and dying — in your throat. A sly, mordantly funny, at times brutal satire about altruism and its discontents, the movie offers something of an emotional workout. One minute you’re grooving on the story and the nice, warm feeling you get from watching Romanian charity workers dole out food and treats for Christmas. The next you’re squirming as they lose their bearings and their good intentions go ridiculously awry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Jeff Zients to Leave as Biden’s Covid Czar and Be Replaced by Ashish Jha
description: The choice of Dr. Jha, an outspoken public health expert, is a sign that the White House believes the country is entering a new phase of the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey D. Zients, an entrepreneur and management consultant who steered President Biden’s coronavirus response through successive pandemic waves and the largest vaccination campaign in American history, plans to leave the White House in April to return to private life, President Biden said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Louisiana Student Recorded Whipping Black Classmate Is Charged With Hate Crime
description: The 15-year-old, who also appeared to throw cotton balls at the classmate in a video, was arrested on Tuesday in connection with the episode, which “appears to be racially motivated.”
content: A Louisiana high school student who was captured on video appearing to throw cotton balls at a Black student and whip him several times with a belt was arrested on Tuesday on a hate crime charge, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: A New Name for California’s Oldest Law School? It’s Not Easy.
description: The University of California, Hastings College of the Law has decided to dissociate itself from its founder for his role in massacres of Native Americans.
content: When a New York Times article last year detailed the involvement of the founder of the University of California, Hastings College of the Law in state-sponsored massacres of Indigenous Californians, an outcry ensued. The law school’s board swiftly and unanimously agreed to change the school’s name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Under His Misspell’
description: Has your inner critic ever gotten in the way of relationships?
content: “Under His Misspell” is a three-minute animated film from the Modern Love series that touches on themes of love, relationships, and that voice in your head that says, “this person is right or wrong for me.” It tells the story of what happens when a writer falls in love with someone whose spelling and grammar are poor, challenging her assumptions about the type of man she’d want to marry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Margolick
title: Ralph Terry, Yankee Hurler Redeemed by One Pitch, Dies at 86
description: In 1960 he gave up the home run that handed the Pittsburgh Pirates a World Series victory. Two years later he got the final out of the Series against the San Francisco Giants.
content: Ralph Terry, the Yankees pitcher who threw two of the most dramatic and decisive pitches in baseball history, each of them ending a World Series but with stunningly different outcomes, died on Wednesday at a long-term care facility in Larned, Kan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Curve-Edged Mirrors Worth Looking At
description: Whether arched, ovoid or amorphous, the latest styles are assuming unexpected forms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Sentences Reduced for 2 Americans Convicted of Killing Italian Officer
description: An appeals court confirmed the homicide verdicts but commuted the life terms for both men, handing Finnegan Elder 24 years in prison and Gabriel Natale Hjorth 22.
content: ROME — An appeals court in Rome on Thursday overturned the life sentences of two American men convicted last year of killing a police officer while vacationing in the Italian capital, but it did not absolve them of the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Rosenberg
title: Bridget Riley, Through Her Own Eyes
description: Britain’s pre-eminent abstract painter looks anew at her career, from her black-and-white 1960s Op Art to her contemporary explorations with color.
content: “I’m always interested in the beginnings of other artists’ work,” Bridget Riley says. “How they start is quite important.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing

author: By Niki Kitsantonis, Christina Anderson and Emma Bubola
title: Countries previously hostile to refugees embrace Ukrainians.
description: While the warm welcome has been applauded, some human rights advocates point to a humanitarian double standard when it comes to refugees from the Middle East and Africa.
content: As the war in Ukraine triggers a mass exodus of refugees, countries have opened their doors wide to Ukrainians, offering a warm welcome that has historically been denied to other populations fleeing conflicts across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lynn Yeakel, Spurred Into Politics by Anita Hill, Dies at 80
description: She nearly unseated Senator Arlen Specter after his aggressive grilling of Ms. Hill during Clarence Thomas’s 1991 Supreme Court confirmation hearings.
content: For a brief period in 1992, Lynn Yeakel carried the hope of many American women on her shoulders.

description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday March 17, 2022.

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Something Seemed to Be Blocking Signals to Her Brain. What Was It?
description: All her life she had perfect vision — until it suddenly started going haywire.
content: “You can’t see the ceiling, can you?” the man asked his 31-year-old wife. She grimaced, then shook her head. She was lying in bed looking toward the familiar shadows and shapes cast by the wintry morning sun. But she couldn’t see them. It was as if a dense white fog lay between her and those daily shifting patterns. Squinting didn’t help. Opening her eyes as wide as she could didn’t, either. All her life she had perfect vision. It was a secret source of pride. She’d never even seen an eye doctor. But that morning changed everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Ingemi
title: After Years Away, These Teams Are Back on Basketball’s Big Stage
description: Some teams — like Illinois State and Massachusetts — will have already made history before taking the floor.
content: The N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments always represent the chance to make history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: War Strands Ukrainian and Russian Tourists Together in Egyptian Resorts
description: The tension in hotels and on Red Sea beaches is palpable, though there are also moments of compassion.
content: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The five-star resort on the shores of the Red Sea offers 20 all-you-can-eat restaurants and bars, a water park, a deluxe spa, nightly entertainment, snorkeling, sunset yoga and aqua Zumba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Do You Wish Lawmakers Knew About How Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Legislation Affects Teenagers?
description: Teenagers: Tell us how the “Don’t Say Gay” bill in Florida could affect you or others.
content: A bill that aims to restrict Florida public schools from teaching about sexual orientation and gender identity has passed both houses of the state’s legislature. It is a part of “a wave of anti-L.G.B.T.Q. crackdowns by conservative politicians,” Maggie Haberman writes, also pointing to the efforts of Greg Abbott, the governor of Texas, to classify widely accepted medical treatments for transgender adolescents as “child abuse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: A Gender Revolution Is Brewing in New Zealand Rugby
description: One in five rugby players in New Zealand are now women, and their numbers are rising. But persistent stereotypes are proving hard to dismantle.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Les Elder played her first game of rugby when she was 8. The boys’ team in the rural New Zealand town where she lived, Taumarunui, was short a player, and Elder had just come off the netball court. As she played, something clicked. “I just loved the physicality and challenge of the game,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: When Will Publishing Stop Starving Its Young?
description: Two days after Olivie Blake’s novel “The Atlas Six” hit the best-seller list, her editor posted a strongly worded resignation letter on Twitter.
content: TITAN OF INDUSTRY On the copyright page of Olivie Blake’s fantasy novel “The Atlas Six,” readers might notice an unobtrusive line of print above the ISBN data and below the title. It says, “Edited by Molly McGhee.” In her lengthy acknowledgments section, the formerly self-published author and BookTok sensation whose real name is Alexene Farol Follmuth writes, “Thank you to Molly McGhee, my beloved editor, who soothes my!!!s and???s me at all the right moments. You have contributed so much more to this book and to my earthly existence than you will ever know.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Birthday Surprises
description: A woman has trouble keeping her curiosity in check.
content: Grace writes: I have a wonderful boyfriend, Alex, who plans fun surprises for my birthday. I love it, but I’m guilty of badgering him for details in advance. He recently said he would start telling me the truth when I asked. Please order him not to do this and instead accept this behavior as part of the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Cambodia Convicts 19 Opposition Politicians on ‘Incitement’ Charges
description: Critics called the trial a “witch hunt,” and the latest effort by Prime Minister Hun Sen to eliminate the last vestiges of dissenting political voices in what was already a virtually one-party state.
content: BANGKOK — A Cambodian court convicted 19 members of the country’s main opposition party on charges of “incitement” and “conspiracy” on Thursday, as Prime Minister Hun Sen pushed forward with a set of trials that critics condemn as the latest effort to eliminate the last vestiges of dissenting political voices in what is already a virtually one-party state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: The Irish Found Their Luck in the Ivy League
description: Losing last year’s season to the pandemic, and other Ivy League rules, led to an exodus of talent. One of those players, Paul Atkinson, hit a game-winning shot for Notre Dame in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
content: SAN DIEGO — The clock had barely ticked into St. Patrick’s Day when Paul Atkinson Jr. scored the game-winner on a putback layup with 1.4 seconds remaining in the second overtime to, crushingly, send Rutgers home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Pogash
title: Rebuilding Her Life While She Builds Homes
description: Female construction workers are still a rarity, but they are on the rise. After personal losses and three bouts of Covid-19, Deyonna Hancock is finding a new start in the industry.
content: As part of a weekly series on changes in the workplace for women, we’re profiling those who stepped up at a moment of crisis and filled gaps in the labor market during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville, Eshe Nelson and Lananh Nguyen
title: Russia appears to have avoided default as it makes a $117 million bond payment.
description: Sanctions have isolated the country financially, driven down the value of the ruble and cut off Moscow’s access to about half its foreign currency reserves.
content: Russia appeared to avoid a default this week after it made interest payments totaling $117 million due on two bonds denominated in U.S. dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Rosalía Reserves the Right to Transform
description: The Spanish pop singer, known for her reinvention of flamenco, has smashed together new sounds from the Latin world and beyond on her latest album, “Motomami,” out on Friday.
content: LOS ANGELES — Rosalía, the experimental Spanish pop phenom with a reputation for hyper-speed reinvention, often finds herself solving intricate musical problems of her own making. How, for instance, might she blend reggaeton with jazz? Or flamenco with Auto-Tune?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: In Some Parts of the World, the War in Ukraine Seems Justified
description: In countries friendly toward Russia, people are troubled by the war and loss of life, but some say they think that Putin has a point.
content: To an independent filmmaker in Hanoi, Vietnam, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is a “wise leader.” In Rio de Janeiro, a former restaurant owner said he was convinced that Ukraine had hired actors to fake war injuries. And a 27-year-old doctor living near Nairobi in Kenya questioned how Americans could be outraged over the Russian invasion when “for so long, they had a monopoly over anarchy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Another Dictator Is Having a Bad Year
description: Covid is becoming China’s equivalent of Ukraine.
content: The term “dictator” comes from ancient Rome — a man whom the republic would temporarily give absolute authority during crises. The advantages of untrammeled power in a crisis are obvious. A dictator can act quickly — no need to spend months negotiating legislation or fighting legal challenges. And he can impose necessary but unpopular policies. So there are times when autocratic rule can look more effective than the messiness of democracies bound by rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: As one of the first art festivals impacted by the pandemic, Asia Week New York, the annual showcase of Asian arts and antiquities, is back at full strength this year. Twenty-two galleries will offer in-person exhibitions throughout Manhattan; four will display works virtually, maintaining the digital component the festival has rolled out over the past two years. In addition, six auction houses will hold a score of art sales, and major museums, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Japan Society, are planning a range of shows and talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Biden calls Putin a ‘war criminal,’ in his latest verbal escalation against Russia.
description: The U.S. president’s unscripted remarks echoed comments other American officials have made recently.
content: The rhetorical clash between the United States and Russia escalated on Wednesday when President Biden said that he believed President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was a “war criminal,” and a top Russian official said the comment was “unacceptable and unforgivable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘X’ Review: Trash, Art and the Movies
description: Ti West’s latest is a slasher film about the making of a porno film, but the result might not be what you expect.
content: “X” is a clever and exuberant throwback to a less innocent time, when movies could be naughty, disreputable and idiosyncratic. Two kinds of movie in particular: the dirty kind and the scary kind. Set in 1979, before the internet made pornography ubiquitous and before anyone was pontificating about “elevated horror,” this sly and nasty picture insists that the flesh and blood of down-and-dirty entertainment is, literally, flesh and blood.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Calls Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ but Consequences Are Unclear

content: WASHINGTON — A day after President Biden branded President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a “war criminal” over civilian deaths in Ukraine, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Thursday echoed his assessment and said Mr. Putin would be held accountable.

title: Barrie R. Cassileth, Who Transformed Cancer Care, Dies at 83
description: By advocating for acupuncture and other treatments, she helped countless patients weather the pain of chemotherapy and radiation.
content: Barrie R. Cassileth, whose efforts to bring treatments like acupuncture and massage into mainstream cancer care helped countless patients weather the pain of chemotherapy, radiation and terminal illness, died on Feb. 26 at an assisted-living home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate Activists Flex Their Political Muscle
description: Environmental groups want Democrats to confront oil companies over high gas prices. And Democrats are listening.
content: At the urging of environmental groups, Democrats are going on the offensive on gas prices — hitting energy companies with a populist message that puts the party squarely at odds with Republicans and the oil industry.
